instruction: What kinds of spectral feature processing methods were used to map soil organic carbon (SOC) content in the Qinghai-Tibet Plateau (QTP)?
Output: In the related study, the spectral feature processing methods used were partial least squares regression (PLSR), support vector machines (SVM), random forest (RF), and artificial neural network (ANN).

instruction: What metric was chosen to map soil organic carbon (SOC) content in the Qinghai-Tibet Plateau (QTP)?
Output: Machine learning methods were chosen to map soil organic carbon (SOC) content in the Qinghai-Tibet Plateau (QTP).

instruction: What spectrum can be used to map soil organic carbon (SOC) content in the Qinghai-Tibet Plateau (QTP)?
Output: The related study used remote sensing spectrum to map soil organic carbon (SOC) content in the Qinghai-Tibet Plateau (QTP).

instruction: What were the covariates used in the construction of spatial prediction models to map soil organic carbon (SOC) content in the Qinghai-Tibet Plateau (QTP)?
Output: The covariates used in the construction of spatial prediction models to map soil organic carbon (SOC) content in the Qinghai-Tibet Plateau (QTP) were SOC_250m, B2, B11, Soil-Adjusted Vegetation Index (SAVI), Normalized Difference Vegetation Index (NDVI), B5, and Soil-Adjusted Total Vegetation Index (SATVI).

instruction: Can the random forest (RF) model, which outperformed other machine learning methods in mapping soil organic carbon (SOC) content in the Qinghai-Tibet Plateau (QTP), be considered a superior spectral feature processing method compared to traditional methods?
Output: No. Based on the information provided in the related study, it is not possible to determine whether the random forest (RF) model can be considered a superior spectral feature processing method compared to traditional methods. The related study mentions that the RF model outperformed other machine learning methods in mapping SOC content in the QTP, but it does not provide a direct comparison to traditional methods of spectral feature processing. Therefore, further information is needed to make a comparison between the RF model and traditional methods.
